explanation: To determine whether the target function uses any compiler language extensions you must inspect the definitions/expansions of the identifiers and macros that make up the function body and its direct call. - OS_CHECK_POINTER: This is a macro used twice in the function. Macros commonly hide compiler extensions (GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, inline asm, __attribute__ annotations, nested statements, etc.). Inspect the macro expansion to ensure no extension is used. - OS_ObjectIdFindByName: The call target may be a macro or inline function that uses extensions; check its definition or prototype (and any macro that maps to it) for statement-expressions, attributes, nested functions, asm, nonstandard keywords, etc. - LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: This macro/constant is passed into OS_ObjectIdFindByName and could be defined using extension constructs (complex macros, computed expressions, or nonstandard types); its definition must be checked. - osal_id_t: This typedef/type name must be inspected to ensure it is a standard C typedef (not an implementation-specific or compiler-only type, e.g., __int128 or vendor-specific typedefs requiring extensions). - int32: This integer type alias must be checked for how it is defined (macro typedef to compiler-specific type or alias using extension). - OS_printf: Included because OS_CHECK_POINTER or other macros may expand to calls to OS_printf (the call graph shows OS_printf as a callee). Its prototype or any macros around it should be checked for varargs handling or attributes that are compiler-specific. Inspecting these symbols (their macro expansions, typedefs, and function declarations/definitions) is sufficient to establish whether the target function itself or the constructs it directly uses rely on language/compiler extensions.
